Array functionsÂ¶

Numpy functions

Isopy arrays are compatible with most numpy functions:

>>> array = isopy.tb.make_ms_array('pd')
>>> np.log(array)
(row) , 102Pd    , 104Pd    , 105Pd    , 106Pd    , 108Pd    , 110Pd
None  , -4.58537 , -2.19463 , -1.49924 , -1.29719 , -1.32954 , -2.14387

For numpy functions that take an axis argument the function is by default applied to each column:

>>> array = isopy.tb.make_ms_beams('pd', integrations=10)
>>> np.mean(array)
(row) , 102Pd   , 104Pd   , 105Pd   , 106Pd   , 108Pd   , 110Pd
None  , 0.37322 , 4.07611 , 8.17043 , 9.99998 , 9.68167 , 4.28836

However, you can specify the axis to apply the function over a different axis:

>>> np.mean(array, axis=None) #Performes the function over the entire array
6.098293273315375

>>> np.mean(array, axis=0) #Performes the function on each column. Same as omitting the axis argument
(row) , 102Pd   , 104Pd   , 105Pd   , 106Pd   , 108Pd   , 110Pd
None  , 0.37322 , 4.07611 , 8.17043 , 9.99998 , 9.68167 , 4.28836

>>> np.mean(array, axis=1) #Performes the function on each row in the array
array([6.09832176, 6.098316  , 6.09826115, 6.09826404, 6.09823369,
       6.09835421, 6.09827056, 6.09831986, 6.09832989, 6.09826158])

Isopy functions

Isopy has a number of its own array functions that behave like numpy array functions.

The following array functions will accept both numpy like arrays and isopy arrays as input.

sd(a[,Â axis,Â level])

Compute the standard deviation along the specified axis for N-1 degrees of freedom.

nansd(a[,Â axis,Â level])

Compute the standard deviation along the specified axis for N-1 degrees of freedom, while ignoring NaNs.

se(a[,Â axis,Â level])

Compute the standard error along the specified axis for N-1 degrees of freedom.

nanse(a[,Â axis,Â level])

Compute the standard error along the specified axis for N-1 degrees of freedom, while ignoring NaNs.

mad(a[,Â axis,Â scale,Â level])

Compute the median absolute deviation of the data along the given axis.

nanmad(a[,Â axis,Â scale,Â level])

Compute the median absolute deviation along the specified axis, while ignoring NaNs.

count_finite(a[,Â axis])

Count all values in array that are not NaN or Inf along the specified axis.

The following isopy array functions require that at least one isopy array as input.

argmaxkey(a)

Return the name of the column where the largest value of the array is found.

argminkey(a)

Return the name of the column where the smallest value of the array is found.

add(x1,Â x2[,Â default_value])

Add x2 to x1 substituting default_value for absent columns.

subtract(x1,Â x2[,Â default_value])

Subtract x2 from x1 substituting default_value for absent columns.

multiply(x1,Â x2[,Â default_value])

Multiply x1 by x2 substituting default_value for absent columns.

divide(x1,Â x2[,Â default_value])

Divide x1 by x2 substituting default_value for absent columns.

power(x1,Â x2[,Â default_value])

Raise x1 to the power of x2 substituting default_value for absent columns.
